metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax Kerala v. West Coast Chemicals and Industries Ltd.

facts.text: The respondent, West Coast Chemicals and Industries Ltd. (assessee Company), was incorporated in 1937 primarily to acquire and work a match factory at Medical belonging to A. V. Thomas.
Memorandum of Association empowered the Company to manufacture and deal in acids, alkalis and other chemicals.
Assessee Company carried on match manufacturing till account year ending April 30, 1941.
Thereafter, due to war conditions, profits lessened; Company began manufacturing plywood chests for tea, paints and lemon grass oil, permitted by cl. 3 of Memorandum.

On May 9, 1943, assessee entered agreement with Rao Sahib Natesa Iyer to sell lands, buildings, plant and machinery of match factory for Rs. 5,75,000, excluding manufactured goods, chemicals, raw materials; Rs. 57,500 paid upfront, balance in 60 days.
On August 9, 1943, fresh agreement for Rs. 7,35,000, including chemicals and paper for manufacture.
In confidential report to shareholders on August 1, 1944, Directors stated price showed capital appreciation of six times cost price; sale of chemicals resulted in substantial profit.
Assessment for account year ending April 30, 1944, completed by Deputy Commissioner at Rs. 36,498-6-4.
Deputy Commissioner issued notice under s. 25 Travancore Income-tax Act to Company Liquidator for escaped profits from sale of chemicals and paper; assessed Rs. 2 lakhs profit.
Liquidator contended match manufacturing stopped, business wound up, only capital appreciation, not business profit.
Deputy Commissioner relied on Memorandum allowing chemicals manufacture/sale and Directors' report; held liable on Rs. 2 lakhs.
Commissioner on appeal reduced assessable profits to Rs. 1,15,259; Liquidator admitted this profit figure.
Appeal to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal at Trivandrum; assessee contended stock-in-trade sold not in ordinary trading but realisation sale after winding up.
Tribunal found business not completely ceased as Company manufactured on behalf of purchaser; sale had characteristics of trading sale, not realisation.

At assessee request, Tribunal referred two questions to Kerala High Court: (1) whether sale of raw materials with business is revenue sale and Rs. 1,15,259 rightly taxed; (2) whether decision separating sale of machinery/premises from chemicals legally warranted or single transaction.
Prior to chemicals sale to purchaser, only two minor sales: July 24, 1943 to educational institution Rs. 50; October 30, 1943 to stranger Rs. 7-12-0.
Kerala High Court (judgment Jan 27, 1960 in T.R. Case No. 14/1955) held no business done by sale, realisation sale not liable to tax.
Company sold as going concern; worked by assessee on behalf of buyer till payment.

legal_issues.text: Whether the transaction of sale of raw materials (chemicals and paper) along with the business, including machinery, plant and premises, is a revenue sale, and whether Rs. 1,15,259 has been rightly charged to income-tax.

Whether the decision that the sale of match machinery and premises was distinct from the sale of chemicals is legally warranted, and whether there was legally a single transaction of the entire match factory inclusive of raw materials.
Whether there can be said to be a sale in the carrying on of the business in respect of the chemicals and other raw materials.

petitioner_arguments.text: Memorandum of Association empowered manufacturing/selling chemicals; past sales of chemicals; first sale excluded chemicals/raw materials for lower price, second included for higher; identifiable profit Rs. 1,15,259; thus trading profit.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Memorandum of Association; Californian Copper Syndicate v. Harris

petitioner_arguments.text: Business not completely ceased; manufacturing on behalf of purchaser; sale characteristics of trading sale.

respondent_arguments.text: Match manufacturing stopped, business wound up; sale of stock-in-trade was realisation sale after winding up, not in course of ordinary trading; capital appreciation only.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Tebrau Johore Rubber Syndicate Ltd. v. Farmer

court_reasoning.text: Mere realisation of assets is not trading; completion of outstanding contracts post-dissolution/liquidation may be trading; distinction between sales part of trading vs. realisation not act of trading.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cases divided into trading activities or mere realisation.

court_reasoning.text: Analysed Californian Copper (trading as per objects) vs. Tebrau Johore (winding up sale, capital appreciation).
court_reasoning.key_observation: In former, sold as part of trading; latter, winding up.

court_reasoning.text: Doughty v. Commissioner: No trading/profit from book-keeping; slump sale of entire assets not separate stock valuation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sale of entire business as slump transaction is winding up.

court_reasoning.text: Newman (Australia): Sale of entire pastoral property as going concern to end business; capital not trading profit. Anson (NZ): Sheep stock sale as trading profit; doubted by Privy Council.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction: trading sale of whole stock vs. winding up.

court_reasoning.text: J.R. OKane: Sales post-retirement circular still trading till stocks exhausted. Old Bushmills: Similar, on Commissioners' finding.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Depends on whether trading carried on.

court_reasoning.text: Here, match business wound up; sold as going concern but worked on buyer's behalf; no identifiable price for chemicals except by comparing two offers; minor prior sales not evidence of trading in chemicals; MoA clause unused.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Winding up sale to realise capital assets, not trading.

holdings.text: Sale of chemicals and raw materials was a winding up sale with view to realising capital assets, not sale in course of business operations; profit not liable to tax.
True answer is that given by High Court.

precedents_cited.relevance: Profit from sale/exchange assessable if part of trading per company objects.

precedents_cited.case_name: Tebrau Johore Rubber Syndicate Ltd. v. Farmer
precedents_cited.relevance: Sale of acquired properties on winding up is capital appreciation, not profit.
Slump sale of entire assets not trading profit; mere book entry not profit.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Taxation W.A. v. Newman
precedents_cited.relevance: Sale of entire pastoral property to end business is capital, not trading profit.
Entire sheep stock sale as trading profit; doubted by Privy Council.

precedents_cited.case_name: J.R. OKane Co. v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents_cited.relevance: Sales post-retirement still trading till stocks exhausted.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Inland Revenue v. Old Bushmills Distillery Co. Ltd. in Liquidation
precedents_cited.relevance: Decided on Commissioners' finding of ongoing trading.

precedents_cited.case_name: J. and M. Craig Kilmarnock Ltd. v. Cowperthwaite
precedents_cited.relevance: No profit where slump price not apportioned to stock.

statutes_cited.name: Travancore Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Notice issued for escaped assessment of profits.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court upheld the Kerala High Court's decision that the profit of Rs. 1,15,259 from the sale of chemicals and raw materials was a realisation sale on winding up, not a trading profit liable to income-tax.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal dismissed; no tax on the profit.

key_quotes.text: "Mere realisation of assets is not trading but the completion of outstanding contracts after the dissolution of a firm, the commencement of liquidation of a company, or the winding up of the affairs of a trader, has been held to be trading."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key distinction applied to determine nature of sale.

key_quotes.text: "In our judgment, this was a winding up sale with a view to realising the capital assets of the assessee Company and not a sale in the course of business operations, which alone would have attracted tax, if profit resulted."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on why profit not taxable.

key_quotes.text: "the true answer would be the one given by the High Court in the judgment under appeal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
